name: Chocolate Espresso Mousse Cake
description: This cake can be a bit tricky to slice into clean wedges, so I’ve given you a few strategies at the end of the recipe to help. But don’t worry if you don’t get picture-perfect pieces: The best tasting bits of cake are the ones that stick to the side of the knife that you eat yourself, don’t you think? But for safety’s-sake, scrape it off first with a spatula before licking it up. Remember what your mother said would happen if you cut yourself there?
recipeIngredient: 2/3 cup (160ml) brewed espresso or strong coffee

recipeInstructions.text: Lightly butter a 9-inch (23 cm) spring form pan and wrap the outside of the pan with aluminum foil, to seal it watertight. Set the cake pan in a larger pan, such as a roasting pan, large enough to make a water bath or bain marie.
recipeInstructions.name: Lightly butter a 9-inch (23 cm) spring form pan and wrap the outside of the pan with aluminum foil, to seal it watertight. Set the cake pan in a larger pan, such as a roasting pan, large enough to make a water bath or bain marie.

recipeInstructions.text: Put the chopped chocolate with the cream and espresso in a large heatproof bowl.
recipeInstructions.name: Put the chopped chocolate with the cream and espresso in a large heatproof bowl.

recipeInstructions.text: Set the chocolate over a saucepan of simmering water, stirring gently until melted and smooth. Remove from heat.
recipeInstructions.name: Set the chocolate over a saucepan of simmering water, stirring gently until melted and smooth. Remove from heat.

recipeInstructions.text: In a standing electric mixer, whip the eggs, salt, and sugar and whip on high-speed until they hold their shape, about 5 minutes.
recipeInstructions.name: In a standing electric mixer, whip the eggs, salt, and sugar and whip on high-speed until they hold their shape, about 5 minutes.

recipeInstructions.text: Fold half of the whipped eggs into the chocolate, then finish with the remaining eggs.
recipeInstructions.name: Fold half of the whipped eggs into the chocolate, then finish with the remaining eggs.

recipeInstructions.text: Scrape the batter into the prepared cake pan. Add warm water to the roasting pan so that it reaches half-way up the outsides of the spring form pan, creating a water bath.
recipeInstructions.name: Scrape the batter into the prepared cake pan. Add warm water to the roasting pan so that it reaches half-way up the outsides of the spring form pan, creating a water bath.

recipeInstructions.text: Bake for 50 minutes to 1 hour, until the cake is slightly firm, but will still feel soft in the center.
recipeInstructions.name: Bake for 50 minutes to 1 hour, until the cake is slightly firm, but will still feel soft in the center.

recipeInstructions.text: Remove the cake pan from the water bath and set on a cooling rack until room temperature.
recipeInstructions.name: Remove the cake pan from the water bath and set on a cooling rack until room temperature.

recipeInstructions.text: To serve: Slide a knife along the outside edge of the cake pan to release it from the pan. Release the outside ring of the spring form cake pan. Can be served at room temperature or chilled.
